ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

FACTORIES IN DEFU INDUSTRIAL ESTATE
(Particulars)


    1. Mr Sia Kah Hui asked the Minister for National Development (a) how many factories were built by the Housing and Development Board and the private sector in Defu Industrial Estate; and (b) as at 1st June, 1984, how many of those built by the HDB have never been occupied and how many were occupied but later returned.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, 202 factories were built by the HDB and 59 factories by the private sector in Defu Industrial Estate.

    As at 1st June 1984, 36 factories built by the HDB at Defu Industrial Estate have never been occupied. Of these, 16 have been offered to resettlement cases and are due for occupation soon. The remaining 20 are being held vacant to meet the demand from future resettlement cases.

    Two factories were occupied but later returned.

     Mr Sia Kah Hui (Paya Lebar): Sir, how many factories were built by the private sector?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: 59.

Column: 1559

PLANNING APPROVAL FOR HOUSING DEVELOPMENT
(Obligation for Clearance)


    2. Mr Sia Kah Hui asked the Minister for National Development whether he is aware that planning approval for the construction of two semi-detached bungalows was given to a developer after he was asked to pay and paid $86,569.45 to Government for expenses to resite a temple on state land; what was the rationale for this; and how was the sum arrived at.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, in housing developments, developers are sometimes required under the Planning Act to surrender land without encum-

Column: 1560

brances to the Government for public amenities such as roads, open spaces and schools. Developers are thus responsible for the clearance of any squatters on such land. However, it is not uncommon for developers to face clearance difficulties which hold up the surrender of the land, and thus delay the development of public amenities. The Government therefore introduced a new policy in 1980 allowing developers the option of surrendering encumbered land to the Government provided they pay five times the direct clearance cost as well as other indirect costs.

    In the case brought up by the hon. Member for Paya Lebar, the site proposed for housing development had originally been approved for a temple and two detached houses. Subsequently, the developer submitted a fresh proposal in 1978 for six terrace houses. However, it was established that a Chinese temple had been moved into a piece of land which he had surrendered to the State for a school. The Government therefore imposed a condition that the temple must be cleared before his proposal could be considered. The developer subsequently exercised his option to request the Government to clear the temple at his expense. The Government then undertook the clearance of the temple and charged the developer accordingly. Consequently, the developer's application, amended to two pairs of semi-detached houses, was approved in 1983 as he had already discharged his obligation to clear the temple from the land he had surrendered to the Government.

    The cost of $86,569.45 charged to the developer is the sum of the following items:

    (a) five times the direct clearance cost amounting to $34,564.70;

    (b) an administrative charge of $1,382.59;

    (c) an agency fee amounting to $622.16; and

    (d) an indirect cost of $50,000 for the relocation of the temple.

     Mr Sia Kah Hui: Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Minister know that after I have written to the developer who had in writing assured the temple people that he would

Column: 1561

build them a new temple at the developer's expense, his reply to me was that Government had taken over his obligation. And he sent me a copy of a letter from the Permanent Secretary on behalf of the Ministry of National Development, which says:

    'it has been decided to give Government assistance in the clearance of the Chinese temple on condition that you pay to the Government the sum of $86,569.45 to discharge your obligation to clear this temple.'

Therefore, the developer says that the Government had freed him from his obligation to build a new temple.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, any private agreement that may have been made between the developer and the temple has nothing to do with the Government. The Government is not a party to such agreement. The Government cannot absolve any party of any obligation under any private agreement. It does not have the power to do so. If there is a dispute arising from the private agreement, it is up to the party involved to seek legal redress on the matter.

    As far as the Government is concerned, it is the responsibility of the developer to bear the clearance cost for the land surrendered to the Government. This should not be confused with any private agreement that may exist between the developer and the temple.

    The hon. Member for Paya Lebar has previously brought this matter up and my Senior Parliamentary Secretary has given him a detailed reply. I have given permission to the hon. Member to forward a copy of this reply to the developer and the temple to clarify Government's position on this matter.

     Mr Sia Kah Hui: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware of his Parliamentary Secretary's reply? Perhaps he could explain what is the meaning of this sentence:

    'A sum of $86,569.45 was paid to the Government as resettlement cost plus administration charges and agency fees to discharge the developer's obligation to clear the temple.'

This temple was originally at Tai Keng Gardens and the developer had applied to

Column: 1562

the Government to develop the estate, and he wrote this letter. Perhaps the press might like to have a copy. I could give them a copy of this letter from one of our famous developers of international character, that he promised to build a new temple and he removed the altar of the temple to another part of his land that is not affected by the development of Tai Keng Gardens. And he promised in writing that he would build them a brand new and better temple. So now he takes the Government's letter as freeing him from this obligation.

    I think the matter could be cleared up if the Minister were to write another letter to the developer to say that the Government is not freeing him from his obligation but that he should fulfil his obligation to the temple people.

     Mr Speaker: Mr Teh, this is one of the longest supplementary questions I have ever heard!

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, my earlier explanation should be quite clear. The developer has surrendered a piece of land to the Government for the construction of a school. There is a temple on this piece of land surrendered to the Government. So the payment of more than $86,000 for the clearance of the temple is to clear the temple on the State land which the developer surrendered to the Government. And this should not be mixed up with any private agreement that may have been entered into between the developer and the temple. That is a separate issue altogether.

     Mr Sia Kah Hui: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister what difficulty is there that he does not want to clear this up? It is not with me. I understand, but the developer does not. He sends the letter from the Government to the temple saying, "Here you are, you see, I paid this money and there is a receipt. I am free from my obligation. Government is taking over." I am asking whether the Minister would write another letter to the developer to tell him that Government has not freed him from his obligation.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I thought that I have already done so. I have,

Column: 1563

in fact, given permission to the hon. Member for Paya Lebar to forward a copy of my Senior Parliamentary Secretary's letter to the developer and a copy to the temple. The letter is quite clear. But if the Member wants me to send a copy of the letter to the developer and the temple, I will do so.

     Mr Sia Kah Hui: Not a copy of the letter which your Parliamentary Secretary has sent because, as I have read earlier on, this letter is not clear. Because it says, "to discharge your (the developer's) obligation to clear the temple." The developer says, "Here you are. This clearly says so. It clears me from my obligation, Therefore, I am not obliged to build a temple for you even though I have written it before." So I just wanted the Minister to write clearly to the developer that we have not cleared him from his obligation. Because the Parliamentary Secretary's letter says so, and that is the interpretation of the developer. So it is no use my sending this letter to the developer. There is no point because he will say, "There you are. I am cleared of my obligation."

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think my Senior Parliamentary Secretary's letter is quite clear. But if the hon. Member is of the view that it is not clear, I can send another letter to clarify.

     Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, I am not the one who is not clear and I am not the one who is involved in this. It just happened that the developer takes your letter to mean that you are freeing him from his obligation. I would like the Minister to have it clearly stated that the Government is not freeing him from his obligation and that he cannot hide under the skirt of the Government.

Column: 1563

INDIAN MUSLIM KATHIS
(Particulars)


    3. Mr M.K.A. Jabbar asked the Minister for Social Affairs whether there are any registered Indian Muslim Kathis for the solemnization of Muslim marriages in

Column: 1564

Singapore and, if so, their number; and, if there are none, what steps, have been taken to appoint Indian Muslim Kathis.

     The Minister for Social Affairs (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, among the 16 Kadis and Naib Kadis appointed by the President of Singapore to solemnize marriages under the Administration of Muslim Law Act, only one is an Indian Muslim. Since his appointment in September 1977, this Naib Kadi has solemnized a total of only 71 marriages, or an average of 12 each year. The other Kadis and Naib Kadis solemnize an annual average of 176 marriages each during the same period. So it would appear that more Indian Muslim Naib Kadis are not required to serve the needs of the Indian Muslim community in Singapore.

Column: 1564

PROBLEMS OF THE AGED
(Paper Misc. 3 of 1984)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Amendment [29th June, 1984], to Question [29th June, 1984],

    "That this House, having noted the Report of the Committee on the Problems of the Aged - A Blue Paper by the Ministry of Health, February 1984, as contained in Paper Misc. 3 of 1984, approves the recommendations of the Committee on the Problems of the Aged." - (Minister for Health).

    Which Amendment was,

    To leave out "approves the recommendations of the Committee on the Problems of the Aged" appearing in lines 3 and 4 and insert -

    "recommends to the Government to adopt the Report, after making appropriate amendments to the recommendations taking into consideration the views expressed by this House". - [Mr Lim Boon Heng].

     Mr Speaker: The Member for Anson has also given notice of an amendment. The terms of his amendment* are set out in the Order Paper.


    *The amendment, standing in the name of Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam, reads as follows:-

    As a further amendment, "To leave out 'approves the recommendations of the Committee on the Problems of the Aged' appearing in lines 3 and 4 and insert -

    'calls upon the government to reject the proposal of the Committee that the government should consider raising the age for withdrawal of CPF savings at first to 60 and later to 65'.".


    The House has agreed that debate on the Original Question and the amendments moved by the Member for Kebun Baru and to be moved by the Member for Anson be proceeded with in accordance with the proviso to Standing Order 40(1).

Column: 1565



    The Question is, "That the words proposed to be left out, be left out."

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, before I move the amendment, may I first speak on the Motion on the Report itself?

     Mr Speaker: Yes.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, this is a Report on the Problems of the Aged. It is a trite observation but perhaps if I may be permitted, Mr Speaker, Sir, to state that this is not a new problem. Societies from the earliest inception have had an aged population in their midst. The only difference perhaps is that today the ages at which people age are advanced beyond what they were some years ago. So it is not a new problem, and it is not by any means a problem that is only peculiar to Singapore. It is a universal problem that is found wherever we have societies because it is in the nature of man that he must grow old and eventually die.

    I say this, Mr Speaker, Sir, because there appears to have been an attempt to view this problem as an alarming problem in our midst. I think that tendency should be discouraged. It is not an alarming problem. It is a problem that can be coped with and dealt with if the whole community - and here, of course, when I speak of the community, I speak of the Government as well, because the Government is the agency of the community. The Government is not, as it were, something set apart from the community, the Government is part of the community - if the community accepts its responsibilities for every sector of its population, ie it accepts its responsibility for the caring for the aged; it accepts its responsibility for the caring of the young, the education of the children. So it is simply an acceptance of a responsibility which we cannot shirk. I would deprecate even using the term "problem". It is simply, as I say, an acceptance of the responsibility for the caring of people in our midst. And we are, of course, at the moment concerned with a certain category of people in our midst, and that is, our citizens who are aged 65 and above.

Column: 1566



    Mr Speaker, Sir, if I may make a general observation on this Report as a whole. It is, in my view, Sir, much too sketchy a report on the acceptance of the responsibility. There is no proper analysis in this Report, as I see it, of the differing problems that will be encountered amongst the section of the population aged 65 and above. The Report would appear to deal with this as one homogeneous problem but, of course, as has been said, the problems vary. It varies according to the income, according to the age, according to the bodily health capacity of the person. There is no attempt made, as I say, to analyse the problems in these different categories. All that is being attempted is, if I may say so, Mr Speaker, Sir, general paternalistic advice to the community on the problem, The Report is sadly deficient in what steps the Government has in mind, as the agency responsible for the caring of the community entrusted to it, to deal with this sector of our population who will be unable to look after themselves.

    The problem, as has been explained, is really, if one comes to look at it, to be found in those people who are too ill and who need a high level of medical care and nursing care. These are the people who are categorized as Type C. It is they who present the most acute problem. It is they who have the greatest need. Type A referred to in this Report, as the Report itself mentions, need hardly any great care to be accorded to them.

    Speaking in the Budget debates in March this year, Mr Speaker, Sir, I asked the Minister for Social Affairs when we were discussing the estimates for his Ministry about the provision of homes for the aged sick, that is the group categorized by Types B and C in this classification of the University Department of Social Medicine. The Minister admitted that there was at the moment a definite shortage of places for people in this category. He said that whilst there was an abundance of places in homes for the aged, he said there was a definite shortage of places for people in these categories. So we have that as a starting point - that there are not sufficient beds in Singapore today for people who through no fault of their own are totally unable to look after themselves.

Column: 1567

Neither are their relatives able to look after themselves in the majority of cases. Of course, those who are very rich, who are very wealthy, are able to look after their relatives who are bed-ridden but the majority of our people are simply unable to take on this responsibility.

    How does this Report address itself to that group? I find nothing at all here about how that problem is to be dealt with. There is a projection about what the demand would be in the year 2000. This is, Mr Speaker, Sir, at Table 5.2 at page 37. There is also a Table showing the present distribution of the aged population. You will find that out of a total of 6,400, that is, taking the position of Types B and C today, Mr Speaker, Sir, only 3,000 are being catered for in institutions. When we come to the year 2000, out of a total of 12,772 in both these categories, assuming that the rate will remain the same, only about 5,700 will be catered for in institutions, it would appear. But there is a definite growth in actual numbers from 3,000 to 5,700. In another 15 years we will have another 2,700 more people who will be totally unable to look after themselves. If there is a definite shortage of beds for the 3,000 now, what are the plans to see that there will be sufficient beds for the 5,700 in the year 2000?

    The Minister said in his Budget speech that the Government has no plans or does not propose to build any homes for the aged sick. As I said in the Budget speech, Mr Speaker, Sir, all that the Government appeared to be doing in this direction, and as he himself said in his speech, was to appeal to voluntary bodies, to charity organizations, to build more homes for the aged sick. I said then that that was a clear abdication of Government responsibility. And when I say "Government responsibility", I say a clear abdication of the community's responsibility because the community acts through the Government. If the Government does not lead the way, then the community is to be blamed. It is the Government that must lead, must set an example, and if the Government fails in this, it is no good saying it is leaving it all to private charity to let the citizens take care of all this because, "We are not going to do it." That would be a total abdication

Column: 1568

of the Government's responsibility in this aspect. That is one of the aspects on which this Report is strangely silent. There is no adequate analysis of the need, what sort of need will be presented, and how it is going to be met. There is, throughout the whole of this Report, as I said, a moralizing tone, doled out paternalistically to the community that they should all do their part. But what about the Government? What part is the Government doing? What role has Government got in all this? Nothing.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there are some assumptions that are made in this Report which would seem to be implied and which I must question. There is an assumption that if the Government takes over to any great extent, and there is increased Government spending, it will undermine filial piety and civic consciousness. It is suggested that if Government takes over this responsibility to any extent, then private charities, private voluntary bodies and our own citizens will not do anything. I do not know what is the basis for this assumption. It is certainly not the example in other countries. It is certainly not the example in Britain which is often characterized as a welfare state. What is important is that there are some areas where the caring can be done only by the Government at the most economical cost. The Government must recognize that this assumption, that if Government increases its spending it will undermine filial piety and civic consciousness, must not be made an excuse for Government inaction.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I see in this Report figures that directly challenge any such assumption. You find in page 44, paragraph 6.4.7, that in a survey conducted in 1982, "93% of the senior citizens are visited by their children." It goes on to say that "the majority, 60%, receive visits at least once a week." It refers to senior citizens who have been put into institutional homes. "22% receive visits at least once a month, while 11.8% are visited less frequently than once a month. 70% of them receive gifts or money from their children during their visits. Thus, most of our senior citizens now do receive support from their children."

    Then it goes on to say in the next paragraph that 87.7% of our senior citizens

Column: 1569

have stated that they could depend on their family members. So the facts would appear to belie the assumption that if Government steps in with a bit more spending, all the children will give up any caring for their parents. That is a wrong assumption, and I think it is an insult to our community as a whole. I do not think our Singapore citizens have shown that the young are unmindful of the filial respect that they owe their parents. So I do not think we need to lecture to them about it. As I said in previous speeches in this House, at Budget sessions, all that they ask for is that the Government recognizes their needs and gives them practical help and then they will undertake for their part what is necessary. But what they do not want is the Government using this as an excuse for inaction and leaving them to shoulder all the responsibility when, in the majority of cases, they are unable simply to shoulder that responsibility.

    The Minister for Finance, again speaking at the Budget session, said that the income tax reliefs could not be raised because he did not want any of the population to think that they could get anything for free. But there is the other side of this. Our citizens are paying taxes, and what is it that they are getting in return for the taxes that they are paying? Almost every service to the community is charged, not perhaps at the economic cost but there is a charge levied for almost every service. So the citizen may well ask, "Well, what am I paying my taxes for? Even when it comes to caring for the aged sick, you say I have to look after them when I am just simply unable to."

    We are not talking, Mr Speaker, Sir, as I said, of the wealthy, of the rich. They do not need any assistance, any help. We are talking of people who live in one-room HDB flats, two-room HDB flats and even three-room HDB flats who will be unable to shoulder this responsibility. It is to them that the Government owes a responsibility and caring concern. As I said, there is very little in this Report which sets out what is going to be provided in the way of caring for people in this group.

Column: 1570



    May I refer you, Sir, to the Report at Chapter 5 about Social Services and Institutional Care. There it is set out that apart from institutional care there are important services which can be provided to help the community. It goes on to say about these services which have been introduced in other countries successfully. A number of them are set out, such as Domiciliary Nursing Services, Good Neighbour Programmes, Home Help Services, Meal Delivery Services, Day Care Centres, and Respite Services. Then it goes on to say:

    'Of these services, only domiciliary nursing services are at present available in Singapore, and are provided by the Home Nursing Foundation. The other services are suitable for introduction in Singapore.'

That is all - "are suitable for introduction in Singapore." There is not a word as to whether any steps will be taken to provide this sort of service to families. It is that sort of thing that this Report significantly lacks.

    I have referred in this House to letters that have appeared from time to time in the press where our citizens looking after their aged parents have appealed for help, and there have been some letters where they cry out for help. But what is the Government's reply to all that? I would have thought that this Report might have gone on to set out some of the services that can be introduced in Singapore to help our people look after their parents or grandparents. No. Nothing. Much of it remains a speculation.

    Before I move on to the most controversial recommendation, Mr Speaker, may I say that that seems to be the only specific recommendation that this Report has made. There are one or two other aspects of this Report that I would like to talk about, and that is, this suggestion that there should be legislation to legislate for filial piety from our children to their parents. Again, may I say that the findings of the survey which I have just read out would appear to indicate, if you wanted any evidence at all, that there is hardly any need at the present moment for this proposed legislation. Once you make it, as this Report recognizes, a legal duty, as it were, and add to it a sanction for non-performance of that duty, then you rob it of everything. You rob it of the human flow of kindness. You rob it of the love that it

Column: 1571

should spring from, and I would urge the Government to think very carefully before it introduces any legislation to legislate for filial piety. It is not a thing that can be legislated, Mr Speaker, Sir.

    I know that under the Women's Charter, husbands are made responsible for their wives' welfare, and maintenance payments can be ordered against them. But that is on the basis of a contract, marriage being a contract. It is on that basis that that provision has been found. But what is the basis upon which you are going to legislate and make it compulsory for children to support their parents? There is no contractual basis for it. All you can point to is this moral duty, and that is not something that you can legislate for. It can be done but as I have said, our citizens are not lacking in this moral duty. So I cannot see the need for it. But if there is, it can be done through other means, by the inculcation of other values, or other aims in life than materialistic pursuits.

    This Report, again, recognizes, perhaps before it is too late, that the erosion of a lot of these values has been due to the policies of this Government because it has set out materialistic pursuits as the only be-all and end-all of life. So who is responsible for that if there has been an erosion? It is the Government who has been responsible for this erosion. So we do not need any moral legislation. We need less emphasis on material pursuits or pursuits of the material life, and building up of the other values which are more important in a human society.

    I would urge the Government, Sir, not to be hasty in accepting the recommendation to legislate on filial piety.

    Now, I turn, Mr Speaker, Sir, to the one specific, positive recommendation. While it lacks in everything else in what the Government will do, it comes out with this one recommendation, that is, that the age for the withdrawal of the CPF savings should be raised from the present age of 55 to 65. Enough has been said here. Even the Minister in his speech referred to the outcry that has followed this proposal. The rest of the Report has been forgotten. The focus has been turned to this one specific recommendation. Our people are rightly

Column: 1572
